messageBody:
On Wed, 8 Jan 2003 16:08:41 -0600, "Rohrbach, William A."
<william.rohrbach@...> said:
>
> I am trying to run some JUnit tests against a service that is started
> via
> the main() method. This process must be started before I can run my
> JUnit
> test cases. How do I go about starting that service and then running
> the
> test cases against the running service? Do I use the setUp() method to
> start
> a thread to run the service and then run my test cases?
> Thanks,
> Bill

Well, there are a few issues here:

Q. Do you need the service to be invoked only once per set of tests
and then torn down?
A. Yes.
- then use TestSetup
A. No.
- start it in every setUp and stop it in every tearDown

Q. Is it expensive (resources/time/etc.) to start/stop the service?
A. Yes.
- you can
- use TestSetup OR
- use a mock
A. No.
- start it in every setUp and stop it in every tearDown

Q. Does it need to be in a separate thread
A. Yes.
- put it in a separate thread
A. No.
- reduce the complexity of the test by not spawning a thread

Q. Do any of the answers above match the intention of your service
(i.e. expected to run in its own thread or JVM, startUp and shutDown
are expensive, etc.)?
A. Yes.
- use the solution or combination of solutions that match the
intent of the service. Part of what unit testing can be is am
informal but thorough documentation of the intent of the
system!!!
A. No.
- sorry... keep asking questions and we will keep trying to
answer them.

=jason
[:question | ^One]
